intro: Apargia alpina, commonly known as the alpine bluets, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of North America. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its delicate, blue or violet flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, rocky soils at high elevations, often in alpine or subalpine habitats. Its leaves are finely divided and resemble those of other members of its family, while its stems are often hairy. Apargia alpina plays an important role in pollination and is a symbol of the fragile ecosystems found in mountainous environments.
